title: 108_s2051
content: The Act may be cited as the "Animal Feed Protection Act of 2004" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Animal Feed Protection Act of 2004" defines key terms, including "BSE" as bovine spongiform encephalopathy and "covered article" as feed, supplements, medicine, or other ingested items for animals, excluding unprocessed nonanimal agricultural commodities. The "Animal Feed Protection Act of 2004" defines "specified risk material" as parts of animals that may carry prion disease but are necessary for animal or public health protection. The "Animal Feed Protection Act of 2004" defines "specified risk material" as parts of animals that may carry prion disease, including the skull, brain, trigeminal ganglia, eyes, tonsils, spinal cord, vertebral column, or dorsal root ganglia of cattle and bison 30 months of age and older, and sheep, goats, deer, and elk 12 months of age and older. It also includes the intestinal tract of any ruminant and any other material that may carry a prion disease as determined by the Secretary based on scientific research. The Secretary conducts an annual review of research and may modify these regulations. The Secretary may modify the definition of specified risk material based on credible research. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The law prohibits the introduction of animal feed containing specified risk material from a ruminant or material from a ruminant with signs of neurological disease into interstate or foreign commerce. Enforcement of this law is outlined in Section 4. The Secretary and other Federal agencies must cooperate with the Attorney General to enforce the Act. Any person facing enforcement action has the right to an informal hearing within 10 days. Remedies include seizing and destroying violating articles or issuing orders for recall and cessation of violations in interstate or foreign commerce. The Secretary is directed to establish civil and monetary penalties within 180 days to enforce the Act. Penalties may include recalling and refunding the purchase price of violating articles, destroying or forfeiting the articles, or ceasing operations until violations are corrected. SEC. 5. Training standards will be issued by the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, for the removal of specified risk materials. $5,000,000 is authorized to carry out this Act. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment.
